title: How to Drink Baking Soda

methods.name: Mixing and Drinking a Baking Soda Solution

steps.headline: Dissolve 1/2 teaspoon of baking soda in 1/2 cup of water for 1 dose.
steps.description: Pour 1/2 cup (125 ml) of plain water into a glass. Then, measure out 1/2 teaspoon (2 grams) of baking soda and stir it into the glass of water. Keep stirring until the baking soda dissolves completely. This amount is considered to be a single dose.Tip: Make sure you’re using baking soda, not baking powder! They aren’t the same thing, and baking powder isn’t safe to drink.

steps.headline: Drink the solution after you’ve digested your most recent meal.
steps.description: You can take baking soda any time of the day, but it’s important not to consume it on a full stomach. Doing so could cause stomach ruptures. You don’t necessarily have to take it on a completely empty stomach, although that is preferred. Just make sure you’ve digested your last meal before drinking the solution.

steps.headline: Take a single dose once daily for general health benefits.
steps.description: Choose a specific time per day for your dose and be consistent so you don’t forget. It's best not to consume it in the morning, so aim for 1 hour before lunch or 1 hour before your evening meal. Taking more than a single dose per day is usually not recommended and can cause serious health problems, like heart attacks or hyperalkalosis. General health benefits may include improved digestion and immune response.

steps.headline: Monitor how your body responds after drinking baking soda.
steps.description: Drinking too much baking soda can be harmful. Watch for side effects like a racing heart or an irregular heartbeat, which can indicate that you've taken too much or that your body's sodium levels are too high to safely take baking soda. Do not take it again if you experience side effects, and see your doctor to have your sodium levels checked as soon as possible. Vomiting or diarrhea after taking baking soda may indicate that you've taken too much. Contact Poison Control or consider going to the emergency room. If you're nervous about trying baking soda, consider starting with a much smaller dose, like 1/8 teaspoon (0.5 grams) or 1/4 teaspoon (1 gram) dissolved in water.

steps.headline: Discuss this supplement with your doctor if you plan to take it daily.
steps.description:
Small amounts of baking soda are usually considered to be safe for healthy people, but people with certain health problems shouldn’t take it regularly. It’s high in sodium, so it’s not recommended for people with high cholesterol or those on a sodium-restricted diet. Talk to your doctor about taking baking soda if you are on any kind of medication. People who should avoid it altogether:
Women who are pregnant or nursing
Individuals with edema, liver disease, kidney disease, or high blood pressure
Children under the age of 5

methods.name: Treating Different Conditions with Baking Soda

steps.headline: Take baking soda to improve your digestive system.
steps.description: If you suffer from acid reflux, baking soda can help neutralize that acid and provide relief from heartburn. Baking soda may also help your body digest food better, reduce bloating and gas, and promote healthy bowel functioning. Take 1 dose per day, or on the days when you think you might need a digestive aid. Baking soda neutralizes acidity, and the effervescence of the solution eases bloating and gas by encouraging burping.

steps.headline: Use baking soda to lower your body’s overall acidity levels.
steps.description: Baking soda is alkaline, so it neutralizes acids of all kinds. As long as you're healthy, you can try taking baking soda to low acidity levels in your body. High acidity levels have been linked to degenerative diseases like osteoporosis, arthritis, and cancer. Consider taking 1 dose per day to reap consistent benefits.

steps.headline: Treat kidney stones and urinary tract infections with baking soda.
steps.description: The kidneys and urinary tract are both vulnerable to acidic urine. Taking 1 dose of baking soda per day may discourage the formation of kidney stones and help you overcome UTIs more quickly. While baking soda may help with mild kidney problems, it's not recommended for people with kidney disease or renal failure. Reducing the acid levels in urine may also provide relief for people suffering from UTIs.

steps.headline: Prevent sports-related muscle pain and fatigue with baking soda.
steps.description: Intense physical activity causes lactic acid to build up in the body, which leads to pain and fatigue. Drinking baking soda can delay that buildup, which increases performance, endurance, and speed. This treatment is a favorite among professional athletics because of how effective it is. If you’re a professional athlete, talk to your trainer about using baking soda. Because of its performance-enhancing properties, baking soda consumption is banned in some sports.

steps.headline: Shorten the duration of colds and the flu with short-term use of baking soda.
steps.description:
Baking soda can reduce the symptoms associated with the cold and flu, and it’s known to shorten the duration of the illness. This treatment requires frequent and higher doses, so it’s not recommended for prolonged use. To treat a cold or the flu, follow this dosage schedule:

Day 1: 6 doses of baking soda solution every 2 hours

Day 2: 4 doses of baking soda solution every 2 hours

Day 3: 2 doses of baking soda solution in the morning and in the evening
If you’re still feeling symptoms on Day 3, continue taking 1 dose each morning until you feel better.Tip: Baking soda can interfere with the absorption of medications, so you may want to hold off on antibiotics and other treatments if you plan to try this.

steps.headline: Improve your overall immune health by regularly taking baking soda.
steps.description: Regularly consuming baking soda may help to treat auto-immune related conditions like rheumatoid arthritis and gout. Talk to your doctor about using baking soda for this purpose before taking it regularly.
